user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_notify:
```c
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_linux_irq_notify:
static int irq_notify_fd
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 1.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Violation: the metal_log macro expands to a GNU statement-expression ({ ... }) and uses the GCC comma-elision token-pasting idiom (##__VA_ARGS__), both are compiler extensions. Thus the call metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__) invokes code that relies on language extensions (GCC/Clang), violating MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2. Note: __func__ itself is standard C and is not a problem.
